tossups.answer: guns [accept clear equivalents like firearms, accept arquebus, accept muskets, accept answers like pistols or rifles, but do not accept answers specifically referring to later firearms like “revolvers” or “machine guns”, accept Tanegashima before read]

answers: military-industrial complex [accept military-industry complex, or MIC]
parts: Name this three-word phrase describing an “alliance” between America’s defense sector and companies that prop it up. It is often invoked when discussing how businesses profit from war.

A key feature of the military-industrial complex is the close relationship between the Department of Defense and large private military contractors, including this largest one that built the SR-71 and U2 planes.

An early warning against the military-industrial complex was the book “War Is a Racket” by retired General Smedley Butler. In the book, he describes making “Mexico, especially Tampoco, safe for” American interests in this resource and ensuring John D. Rockefeller’s company built on this resource went “unmolested” in “China.”

answers: First Great Awakening [prompt on Great Awakening; do not accept "Second Great Awakening"]
slaves [prompt on African-Americans or Black people]
parts: Name this large religious revival in early to mid-eighteenth century America. The name for the new lights came from a sermon by this movement's preacher Jonathan Edwards.

Virginia clergyman Samuel Davies advocated for the evangelism of these people during the First Great Awakening. These people incorporated Christian beliefs into spirituals as "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot."
This First Great Awakening preacher and advocate of better treatment for slaves lobbied the Georgia colonial government to legalize slavery in order to staff his Bethesda Orphanage with slaves.
